arm_group.description: patients affected with sickle cell disease

brief_summary.textblock:
The investigators' primary objective is to study prevalences of myocardial iron overload,
      defined as a cardiac T2*< 20 ms, in 3 populations of multiply transfused patients, affected
      with thalassemia, sickle cell disease, and myelodysplasia.

clinical_study.brief_title: Multicenter Observational Study on Myocardial Iron Overload in 3 Multitransfused Populations

detailed_description.textblock:
The inevestigators' primary objective is to study prevalences of myocardial iron overload,
      defined as a cardiac T2*< 20 ms, in 3 populations of multiply transfused patients, affected
      with thalassemia, sickle cell disease, and myelodysplasia.

      The investigators will record concomitantly parameters which, according to literature data,
      may influence the occurrence of this complication, and will look for correlations with these
      parameters and iron overload (secondary objectives), in each of the 3 cohorts.

      14 centres are involved and enrol patients with thalassemia, or sickle cell disease, or
      myelodysplasia having received in the past year > 8 erythrocyte concentrates, and having had
      a cardiac MRI. Patients files register the type of the disease, age at the beginning of
      transfusion and chelation, chelator type and dosage, liver and cardiac T2*.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Thalassemia, sickle cell disease, myelodysplasia

          -  having received in the past year > 8 erythrocyte concentrates

          -  > 6 years of age

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  preexisting cardiac disease

study_pop.textblock: patients affected with thalassemia, SCD, and myelodysplasia

intervention.description: a blood sample was taken on the day of inclusion

clinical_study.official_title: Multicenter Observational Study on Myocardial Iron Overload in 3 Multitransfused Populations

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Cohort, Time Perspective: Prospective
